io.spine.base

Class Environment

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.spine.base.Environment
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Logging

    @SPI
public final class Environment
extends java.lang.Object
implements Logging
    Provides information about the environment (current platform used, etc.).

    Detecting the type of the environment

    It is possible to obtain the type of the current environment, or to check whether current environment type matches another type. 

    
 public final class Application {

     private final EmailSender sender;

     private Application() {
         Environment environment = Environment.instance();
         if (environment.is(Tests.class)) {
             // Do not send out emails if in tests.
             this.sender = new MockEmailSender();
         } else {
             this.sender = EmailSender.withConfig("email_gateway.yml");
         }
         //...
     }
 }

    The following standard types are always available for checking with the current environment:

    • Tests is detected if the current call stack has a reference to a unit testing framework.
    • Production is set in all other cases.

    The framework users may define their custom settings depending on the current environment type. Please see CustomEnvironmentType for details.

    When environment changes

    When calculating the current type Environment finds the first enabled EnvironmentType, and then remembers it as the currently active. Subsequent calls will not cause re-evaluation of the EnvironmentType.enabled().

    If later the current type becomes logically inactive, Environment needs to be updated by one of the following approaches:

    • Setting a new environment type, directly by calling setTo(Class).
    • Calling the reset() method. This would drop the currently selected type. 
    
     Environment environment = Environment.instance();
     environment.register(AwsLambda.class);
     assertThat(environment.is(AwsLambda.class)).isTrue();

     System.clearProperty(AwsLambda.AWS_ENV_VARIABLE);

     // Even though `AwsLambda` is not active, we have cached the value, and
     // `is(AwsLambda.class)` is `true`.
     assertThat(environment.is(AwsLambda.class)).isTrue();

     environment.reset();

     // When `reset` explicitly, cached value is erased.
     assertThat(environment.is(AwsLambda.class)).isFalse();
    See Also:
    EnvironmentType, CustomEnvironmentType, Tests, Production

    • Method Detail

      • register

        @CanIgnoreReturnValue
public Environment register(java.lang.Class<? extends CustomEnvironmentType> type)
        Remembers the specified environment type, allowing to determine whether it's enabled later.

        The specified type must have a parameterless constructor. The EnvironmentType is going to be instantiated using the parameterless constructor.

        Parameters:
        type - environment type to register
        Returns:
        this instance of Environment

      • instance

        public static Environment instance()
        Returns the singleton instance.

      • createCopy

        public Environment createCopy()
        Creates a copy of the instance so that it can be later restored via restoreFrom(Environment) by cleanup in tests.

      • is

        public boolean is(java.lang.Class<? extends EnvironmentType> type)
        Determines whether the current environment is the same as the specified one.

        If custom environment types have been registered, the method goes through them in the latest-registered to earliest-registered order. Then, checks Tests and Production.

        Please note that this method follows assigment compatibility: 

        
     abstract class AppEngine extends EnvironmentType {
         ...
     }

     final class AppEngineStandard extends AppEngine {
         ...
     }

     Environment environment = Environment.instance();

     // Assuming we are under App Engine Standard
     assertThat(environment.is(AppEngine.class)).isTrue();
        Returns:
        whether the current environment type matches the specified one

      • type

        public java.lang.Class<? extends EnvironmentType> type()
        Returns the type of the current environment.

        If the type was not selected explicitly before, returns the first one which is enabled, starting from the most recently registered type.

        See Also:
        register(Class)

      • restoreFrom

        public void restoreFrom(Environment copy)
        Restores the state from the instance created by createCopy().

        Call this method when cleaning up tests that modify Environment.

      • setTo

        public void setTo(java.lang.Class<? extends EnvironmentType> type)
        Sets the current environment type to the specified one. Overrides the current value. If the supplied type was not registered previously, it is registered.

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Resets the instance and clears the TestsProperty.

        Erases all registered environment types, leaving only Tests and Production.
